case_vignette: A 23-year-old male presents to his primary care physician after an injury during a rugby game. The patient states that he was tackled and ever since then has had pain in his knee. The patient has tried NSAIDs and ice to no avail. The patient has no past medical history and is currently taking a multivitamin, fish oil, and a whey protein supplement. On physical exam you note a knee that is heavily bruised. It is painful for the patient to bear weight on the knee, and passive motion of the knee elicits some pain. There is laxity at the knee to varus stress. The patient is wondering when he can return to athletics.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've got pain in my knee that started after I was tackled in a rugby game, and it's really bruised.
Is the knee swelling or unable to bear weight?
It hurts to put weight on my knee.
Have you heard a popping sound during the injury?
No, I didn't hear a popping sound when I was injured.
Based on your symptoms, this could be a ligament sprain. Can you tell me if you've had any previous injuries or surgeries on the affected knee?
I have no past medical history of injuries or surgeries on my knee.
Final Diagnosis: Ligament Sprain.

trial_0.vignette_frq: Based on the given symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is a knee ligament injury, specifically a medial collateral ligament (MCL) sprain. However, further diagnostic tests such as an X-ray or MRI may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the injury. These conditions are commonly caused by blows to the knee and result in pain, bruising, and difficulty bearing weight. They do not typically involve a popping sound.
